questiontext.text:
The table below summarises the test results obtained from a set of strength tests on the concrete produced by two laboratories. Formulate a two-sample t-test to determine whether the products produced by them are different at a significance level 5%

28 day strength (MPa)
Laboratory 1Laboratory 2
53.2049.90
37.5053.00
53.3046.40
47.7049.20
36.9054.20
40.5053.00
45.9054.60
54.2051.60
54.3045.30
38.1053.50
54.5054.40
54.2051.80


Answer:
t* = {1:NUMERICAL:=-1.67:0.01#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}
The strength of the concrete produced by the two labs are:
{1:MCV:~Not Equal#~=Equal#}

generalfeedback.text:
We set up a two-tail test of hypotheses where the hypotheses are formulated as:

Null hypothesis (Ho): the strengths of the concrete produced by the two labs are equal
Alt. hypothesis (Ha): the strengths of the concrete produced by the two labs are not equal

Mean strength of concrete produced by Lab 1: $$ \small \bar{X}_1 = 47.53 $$
Mean strength of concrete produced by Lab 2: $$ \small \bar{X}_2 = 51.41 $$

Standard dev. of strength of concrete produced by Lab 1: $$ \small \sigma_1 = 7.41 $$
Standard dev. of strength of concrete produced by Lab 2: $$ \small \sigma_2 = 3.11 $$

Sample size $$ \small n_1 = n_2 = 12 $$

Calculate the two-sample t statistics as:
$$ \small t^* = \frac{\bar{X}_1 - \bar{X}_2}{\sqrt{\frac{{\sigma_1}^2}{n_1} + \frac{{\sigma_2}^2}{n_2}}} = -1.67$$
At 5% significance level, the critical value of t (with degree of freedom: 12-1 = 11) for rejecting the null hypothesis is t* = -2.59

Hence the null hypothesis cannot be rejected
